title: Esther Chemnitz
text:
Hello, my name is Esther Chemnitz. I’m a Ph.D. fellow at the Department of Political Science at Aarhus University, where I work with fantastic colleagues on the research project ROPH (Research on Online Political Hostility).
My academic background is a patchwork with a BA in Media studies, a short detour around political science, and an MA in Cognition and Communication from the University of Copenhagen. I was even a cabinet maker at one point.
What occupies me at the moment is to understand when public online conversations are possible from a pragmatic or language-use perspective.
My interest in this topic reflects my academic background. I draw on the cognitive literature on language use and interactive processes in conversation (see eg. Herbert Clark, Deanna Wilkes Gibbs, Susan Brennan). And on the work of media scholars like danah boyd, Alice Marwick, Eden Litt, Ezster Hargittai, Joshua Meyrowitz, Nancy Baym and many others.
I am a strong proponent of interdisciplinarity and I believe that research should be (and inevitably is) a collaborative process. My thoughts and ideas are not created in a vaccuum, rather they are continuously fed by other scholars, by popular culture and from observing the world around me.
I also have two kids under 6 who keep me busy when I am not working.

title: The angry internet
text:
This was a project initiated by the Nordic Council of Ministers, which requested an assessment of the extent of online misogyny and antifeminism in the Nordic countries. It was carried out by the Centre for Digital Youth Care and by Analyse & Tal, f.m.b.a.. I contributed with research on the cognitive aspects that allow some groups to uphold misperceptions as well as the potential effects of attempting to correct their views (see pre-print on this topic under Publications) I was also a part of the Expert Advisory Board.
